I'd have to think that when you put four old S.O.B.'s on the cover of a magazine, it's gonna drop magazine sales pretty bad. The techs around Sara laugh. She just shakes her head.
JAY LENO does his monologue.

Did you read this? NASA is training four guys in their late sixties to go on the next shuttle mission. I'm not kidding. So far, NASA's biggest fear is that these guys are gonna spend the entire launch doing 50 in the left hand lane.
(MORE)

(off light laughter) Brand new shuttle too. They had to make a few modifications, though. Like putting phone books on the seats so the astronauts can see above the wheel... Behind Jay, Frank, Hawk, Jerry and Tank appear from behind the curtain, wearing their leather flight jackets. The crowd applauds wildly. Jay thinks it's for him.

Everybody at NASA loves these guys, they're very popular. Okay, there have been a few complaints from the ground crew. Apparently these guys keep putting those 'My grandchild is an honor student' bumper stickers on the back of the  77. shuttle, and the ground crew has to keep scraping them off... Frank eggs on the crowd with a thumbs down. The crowd starts to heckle Jay. Frank and Tank lift up Jay, "surprising" him, and they start to escort him off the stage.
Stick around. We've got Sandra Bullock, Buck Owens, and these guys!
Frank, Hawk, Tank and Jerry sit on the couch next to Jay.
Forget all this Right Stuff crap -- let's cut to the chase. I understand one of you is just a machine with the chicks... (looks at Hawk) Gotta be you, sir. Hawk shakes his head, points to Jerry.
Jay, it's like I tell these clowns, you can't just know what a woman needs, you have to know what a woman wants.
Watching it on TV, laughing hysterically.
And you, sir. Is it true that you are a Baptist Minister?
That's right, my son.

And your name is Tank? A preacher named Tank? Tank rolls up his sleeve, shows his new tattoo -- a cross with rocket exhaust coming out, headed for the stars. The audience loves it. Sara's PHONE RINGS. She ignores it, letting the MACHINE ANSWER. GERSON leaves an ANGRY MESSAGE. She turns the TV VOLUME UP to drown him out.
Two NASA T-38 TRAINER JETS SCREAM by. Hawk and Roger practicing more approaches, each in his own jet, talking by radio.
Follow me, Colonel. We're going to come in at forty degrees. This simulates the attitude of the ship on glide slope.
The Flying Brick...
That's correct.
After you, Rog.
Please don't call me 'Rog.
Roger, 'Rog.' Roger, annoyed, takes his jet in. Fighting it, he sets the plane down for a bumpy landing... then lights the AFTERBURNERS into another take-off roll, climbing hard into the sky.

Lines his jet up, humming to himself. And just to make it interesting, does a Snap Roll with the jet at 500 feet before taking her in for a perfect Touch & Go. He lights the AFTERBURNERS and the JET SCREAMS skyward in a vertica climb.
Something like that?
(impressed) Yeah. Something like that.
Can I call you 'Rog' now?
Yeah. You can call me 'Rog' now.
The Neutral Buoyancy Lab. A giant pool where the astro- nauts train for weightless work.

Frank, Jerry, and Tank in cumbersome space suits, do repairs on a mock satellite. Divers stand by alongside. Ethan is at poolside, on headset, observing the procedure on the video screen looking frustrated.
The lead is connected here, across the relay.
You're a genius, Frank. Frank gives the divers a thumbs up. Frank, Jerry and Tank are lifted out of the water by cranes. Once out, techs help them removes their helmets. Ethan walks over.
So the relay patch is the key?
Plain as the nose on your face.
How did you by-pass the heat exchanger?
I didn't by-pass anything.
You're not being very forthcoming on the workings of the guidance system --
I've tried everything short of calculus lessons to get you to understand this thing. What do you want me to do -- draw you a picture, connect the dots for you?
Excuse me. I hold two Masters Degrees from M.I.T., Dr. Corvin.
I'd get my money back.  80.
Ethan, you've been trained on a different set of technologies. That's all.
(ignoring Jerry, to Frank) You're compromising this mission. I'm your backup. I am on a need- to-know basis.
You don't need-to-know shit. And I don't need a backup.
Yes, you do. More than you know.
(stops, turns) What is that supposed to mean? Ethan realizes too late that he's said too much. Frank looks suspicious, paranoid, furious.
What don't I know? (as Ethan holds his tongue) What don't I know?!
Gerson is in a tele-conference (via video feed) with a Suited Man appearing on a laptop computer which sits on his desk.
Let me spell it out for you, Bob. P-R spells bud-get. Frank bursts into the room, pointing a finger at Gerson.
You're setting me up again!
Here's one of our astronauts now. Frank, what a semi-pleasant surprise.
You sonofabitch! You had no intention of sending me up.  81.
Frank, I'm in the middle of something just now. Frank angrily slams Gerson's laptop shut, terminating the call. Gerson smiles smugly.
You just hung up on the head of our program, the Vice President. So what can I do for you, Frank? Frank quakes with anger. Red-faced, snorting loudly.
You had no intention of sending me up, did you?! You screwed me over in '58 and you're screwing me over now -- !
Screwed you over -- ?
You lied to me again. How could I be so stupid as to make a deal with a chronic liar?!

Deal, Frank? You blackmailed me. I didn't make any 'deal' with you. But whatever you want to call it -- you lost. I don't have to send you up. Frank looks confused. Gerson hands Frank a printout of a lab report. Frank looks it over; it makes no sense to him.
I don't know what this shit means.

It means someone didn't pass his physical. One of you has cancer. Frank goes white, tentatively turns the page over of the lab report, sees in cruel, military typeface: "HAWKINS, WILLIAM B." Frank's mouth goes dry.
It's his pancreas. And it's inoperable.
Does he know?  82.
Dr. Caruthers told him this morning. Frank shakes his head, getting angry again.
No. I don't trust you! This is bullshit! He tears up the lab report, throws the scraps on Gerson's desk.

I want independent tests done by independent doctors -- not ones you bankroll to lie for you and print up bullshit lab results! (catches his breath) This is low, even by your standards. Just to keep me from going into space. Gerson smiles smugly.

Oh, that's what this drama is all about? And this whole time I thought it was Hawk, your friend. But it's really your seat on the space shuttle, isn't it? You can rest easy, Frank. NASA is still sending you, Jerry and Tank up on the shuttle -- regardless of the ‘deal' you and I made.
I don't understand.

You're front page news, Frank. A real American hero. You've made NASA popular all over again. Thanks to you, they're gonna get that juicy budget infusion they've been drooling over. Oh, you're going, Frank. The Vice President insists. Gerson opens up the laptop, prepares to reconnect.
Now if you'll excuse me, I have to call the head of our space program back and apologize for the interruption. Like a zombie, Frank wanders out of the office.  83.
Frank wanders down the corridor, lost in painful thought. People greet him as they pass, but he doesn't hear them.
Across from the space center complex. One of NASA's and the Air Force's storage garages. High-performance aircraft are lined up silently and eerily still, as though waiting.
is Hawk, dressed in civilian clothes. He walks the plane silently, deep in thought. As he ducks under the fuselage, he sees --
watching him walk the plane. The obvious doesn't need to be said.
This was my Blackbird. I retired this very airplane in '90. And here she is.
I've never actually seen one before. Hawk smiles like a proud parent showing off his kid.

SR-71. This is what a plane's supposed to be. She's ugly on the ground, leaks like a sieve. But up around mach one, her seals all expand, she dries up and leans into the wind and goes like hell. I took her right to the edge. 128,000 feet. He runs his hand along the plane's skin, softly, reverently.
She's only happy up there, goin' fast. She's not meant to be sitting on the ground. That's a lousy way to die. Sitting around, waiting...  84. (pauses) Eight months. That's the best I can do, huh?
They don't know that for sure. There's chemo. Radiation.
(shakes his head) I watched my wife go out that way. I ain't taking that road. She nods, making sense of the other evening.
(softly) The love of your life.
(changing the subject) Where the hell is the pancreas, anyway? I don't even know what the damn thing does beside give you cancer. They share a weak laugh.
What odds would you have given us?
Better than forty. She smiles coyly. He kisses her and they hug.
approaches tentatively from the other end of the hangar. He sees Hawk and Sara break out of the hug and say a few words. Frank stops and waits respectfully. Sara walks away from Hawk, passing Frank.
Hi, Frank.
Sara. Frank approaches Hawk, can't find the words.
I'm sorry, Frank. I know how much this flight meant to you. Looks like I crashed another one. I'm sorry.  85. Frank dreads what he has to say next.
They still want to send us up. Me, Jerry and Tank. Hawk thinks on this, smiles slowly.
Well, that's great, Frank. You played these guys perfectly. (off Frank's worried look) You said yes, right?
I didn't say anything.
Don't be an ass, Frank. Don't blow it a second time -- this is your last shot!
This isn't easy, Hawk...
Easy? Don't whine to me about easy.
Put yourself in my shoes --
Oh no you don't. You've blamed me for Daedalus for 40 damn years! You're not laying this one on me! You choke this one, it's you. All you!
What would you do?
I'd leave you behind in a heartbeat! Frank's temper starts to cook -- which is just what Hawk wanted.
You would, wouldn't you?
To go into space? Bet your ass, boy. In a heartbeat. Hawk turns on his heels and walks off. He stops and  86. spins around.
You know what the worst day in my life was, Frank? The day I met you and you put the idea in my head that I could pilot a ship into space. He turns and walks off. Frank watches him go.
The mammoth hangar is the height of a thirty-story skyscraper, but we can't tell from this angle. Frank shows his clearance badge to the SECURITY GUARDS at the door.
How can I help you, Colonel?
I just wanted to go inside and have a look.
Everyone's left for the night, tomorrow's roll-out, you know.
That's okay, I want to be alone.
Yes, sir. (opens door) By the way, I thought you might find it funny: My daughter has a photo of you on her wall next to Leonardo DiCaprio.

And why would I find that funny? Frank winks, pats the guy on the shoulder. And goes -- INT. VEHICLE ASSEMBLY PLANT —- CONTINUOUS ACTION We STAY TIGHT ON Frank as he walks across the expansive floor, looking up at something. (NOTE: This is the biggest enclosed space in the world, but we don't get the sense of that yet.) Frank sits down on the floor, props himself up against the wall. He sticks a piece of bubble gum in his mouth, chews, blows a bubble as he looks up at it...  87.
FRANK — LATER in the same position, only sound asleep. An enormous MOTOR WHIRS as daylight streams across Frank's face. His eyes squint open, and he looks over at the light, coming from --
rolling apart, letting in a slit of light a foot wide and thirty stories high. The light hits --

sitting on its enormous roll-out platform. Rays of sunlight play on the brand new titanium skin and protective tiles. She's positively gleaming in the morning sun, her fuel tanks and solid rocket boosters dwarfing everything around it, including --
who stares up in awe at it. The ground crew stands by proudly, preparing for roll- out. A CONSTRUCTION TECH sees Frank.
Sir, are you here for roll-out?

No. He gets up and strides out of the hangar, passing through the slowly-expanding slit of the concrete doors and onto the crawler-way as the one MPH roll-out begins behind him. The ground crew looks at him strangely.
Sara talks with Gerson. Frank enters the room.
I'm not going. Not without Hawk.
You're blackmailing me again, aren't you?  88.
No. I'll teach Ethan everything he needs to know. But I don't go up without Hawk. Frank turns around and exits. Gerson turns slowly to Sara.
Next idea, Miss Holland?
